FAQs.answer: We don’t believe that the current investment world matches the sustainability strive in the younger generation. At make!mpact, we want to change the game and make sustainable investing simple. We empower you with the knowledge, confidence and transparency to make a difference through your investments. No one should have to compromise their sustainability values in order to invest their money.
FAQs.question: What is make!mpact?

FAQs.answer: At make!mpact, we help you get started investing in companies working to both make a profit and to create a positive impact on <bold>your</bold> sustainability values. In our app, you’ll find everything you need to know about investments, sustainability as well as insights into which globally listed companies share your values - all gathered in one place.
FAQs.question: How does it work?

FAQs.answer: Simply said, you choose minimum three sustainability values based on the 17 UN Sustainable Development goals and we match them against the globally listed companies, which support the same values as you. We then showcase the matches, starting with the company that comes closest to your chosen values.
FAQs.question: How do you match the companies?

FAQs.answer: Today, you can sign up to the make!mpact community if you live in the Nordics. As a member, you will be able to access our academy, customized news feed and track how sustainable your investments are.
FAQs.question: In which countries can I use make!mpact?

FAQs.answer: First of all, let’s make one thing clear – make!mpact will <bold>never</bold> take a cut of your investments. Our app will be 100% free for you to use until July 2021, where you will have to pay a small monthly subscription fee that will give you access to our app, community and all of our future events.
FAQs.question: Is make!mpact free?

FAQs.answer: We strongly believe that everyone has their unique sustainability values and we want you to be able to invest according to your own interests. That is why we don’t screen or rate any of the companies listed in the app. It is up to you to rate the sustainable-level of each of the companies based on your <bold>own</bold> values and insights.
FAQs.question: Does make!mpact screen or rate companies based on how sustainable they are?

FAQs.answer: The companies which you see in our app are all members of UN Global Compact. They have all signed an agreement stating that they support the framework of the 17 UN Sustainable Development Goals.
FAQs.question: How does a company qualify to be in the app?

FAQs.answer: Not yet, but we are working on it.
FAQs.question: Can I also be matched with funds in your app?

FAQs.answer: You can always change the values that you chose when you registered. Go to the “matches” page (the heart icon), select “my values” and then simply tap on the values shown in order to select new ones.
FAQs.question: Can I change my values in the app?

FAQs.answer: We only ask you to give us the name of your bank (nothing else), so we can give you a better and more personalised service in the future. If we decide to make a partnership with your bank specifically, we want to make sure that their clients (you) can benefit the most of this partnership.
FAQs.question: Why do I have to give you the name of my bank during registration?

FAQs.answer: All of the information about the global listed companies is publicly available information – taken from the site of UN Global Compact – that we have put into our app in order to visualize the data for you.
FAQs.question: Where does all of the information about the companies in the app come from?

FAQs.answer: We have partnered up with one of the biggest financial data vendor companies in Europe called SIX, who makes it possible for you to see the latest stock prices as well as a graph of how the price of the stock has changed over the years for each company.
FAQs.question: Where do you get all the stock prices for each company from?

FAQs.answer: The 17 UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) were adopted by the United Nations Member States in 2015 with the aim of reaching these goals by 2030. The 17 SDGs are all about achieving a more prosperous, equitable, and sustainable world.
FAQs.question: What are the 17 Sustainable Development Goals?

FAQs.answer: We have integrated a lot of external initiatives, programs, rankings, verifications and targets within sustainabilty to give you an additional perspective on the companies’ sustainability profile.
FAQs.question: What are the “commitments”in the app?

FAQs.answer: Once you have found a company in our app that you would like to invest in and you click the “make !mpact” button, you are taken straight to our investment platform partner, where you will be able to carry out the actual investment in <bold>their</bold> universe and on <bold>their</bold> terms.
FAQs.question: Can I invest directly in the make!mpact app?

FAQs.answer: To invest through our investment platform partner, you need a Danish CPR number and we are looking forward to expanding this offer to the rest of the Nordics as soon as possible.
FAQs.question: Can I invest if I don’t live in Denmark?

FAQs.answer: Absolutely nothing – since you are only able to carry out your investments directly through our investment platform partner and not in the make!mpact app itself. So there is no need to worry.
FAQs.question: What will happen to my investments if make!mpact goes out of business?

FAQs.answer: Very simple, just send us an email at deleteme@makeimpact.io and your account will be deleted within 7 working days.
FAQs.question: How do I delete my account?

FAQs.answer: In order to match you with companies that share the same values as you, we ask you to create a profile as well as stating which values matter most to you. Your "matches" are based on factual information and on your selected values during your registration process.
FAQs.question: Why do I have to sign up?

FAQs.answer: To change your personal information in our app, you just have to go to “My profile” and click on “My information” and then you can easily change your name, age, email, phone number etc.
FAQs.question: How do I change my personal information?

FAQs.answer: You can find our Privacy Policy under “About make!mpact”, which is located under “My Profile”.
FAQs.question: Where can I read more about your Privacy Policy?

FAQs.answer: Your user information will only be disclosed and shared with relevant partners in order for us to give you the best possible service. To know more about how we make use of your information, please have a look at our Privacy Policy.
FAQs.question: Who will get access to my user information?

FAQs.answer: If you have a question that hasn’t been answered here, you can always contact us by sending us an email at hello@makeimpact.io
FAQs.question: How do I contact Make!mpact?

FAQs.answer: Impact investments are investments made with the intention to generate positive, measurable social and environmental impact alongside a financial return.
FAQs.question: What is Impact Investing?

FAQs.answer: That’s <bold>you</bold>! We call all of our wonderful make!mpact members “!mpactors”, because through your sustainable investments, you help create the impact that is needed to make a better tomorrow.
FAQs.question: What is an !mpactor?

SASBflags.sasb_flag_description: A business generates greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions through its operations from e.g. factories, power plants and vehicles. 🏭 How a business manages its GHG emissions has an impact on a business' reputational risks and opportunities. 📊 Businesses can look into investing into e.g. more fuel-efficient options if their operations are heavy on fuel use. 🚀

Factories, power plants and vehicles as well as other industrial emissions have a negative impact on air quality. 😰 Therefore, it is important to look at how a business manages its air quality impact. 🤗 Negative impact on air quality includes pollutants such as oxides of nitrogen (NOx), oxides of sulfur (SOx), volatile organic compounds (VOCs), heavy metals, particulate matter, and chlorofluorocarbons. 😱

Businesses have a responsibility to manage their energy consumption. ⚡ This includes e.g. energy consumption of manufacturing products. 🏭 Energy management also consists of how a business manages the energy consumption from its utility providers. 🚨 It can be useful to look into what a business does to optimize its energy consumption and what goals have been set for future use. 🎯

Water and wastewater management are impacted by regional differences in the quality of water resources. 💦 Nonetheless, businesses should manage their water use, water consumption as well as wastewater management. 💧 A business can optimize its water and wastewater management by working with water recycling, efficiency and intensity. 👩‍🚒

Hazardous and non-hazardous waste generated by businesses can have negative impact on the environment. ☢️ An example is waste such as pesticides used in agriculture. 🌾Hazardous and non-hazardous waste management covers areas such as handling and disposal of the waste. 🏭

Environmental impacts cover a business' impact on ecosystems and biodiversity. 🌿 A business has impact on ecosystems and biodiversity e.g. concerning land use of exploration and natural resource extraction. 🚜 A business should manage its environmental impacts by looking at how it affects ecosystems and biodiversity both in its current operations as well as in new projects and constructions. 📑

A business should manage its direct and indirect impacts on human rights. ❤️ This includes assessing where a business has adverse impact on human rights and accounting for how the adverse impacts are handled. 🤔 Moreover, the management also covers a business' community engagement and its impact on local businesses. 🏭

Businesses can be in possession of personal information from customer and user data. 📑 How businesses manage the data can be seen in how they collect data and obtain consent from their users and customers. Additionally, the area covers how businesses manage their customers' and users' expectations on how their data is being handled and used. 🤓

Data security covers how businesses collect and use sensitive customer and user data. 📑 Within data security lies a risk of incidents related to data breaches where data can be leaked including personally identifiable information of customers and users. 🗂 It is, therefore, important that a business has policies and practices in place in relation to IT infrastructure, training of employees as well as other processes to secure customer and user data. 🔐

Access and affordability 🔑 cover a company's ability to ensure access to its services/products for instance in underserved markets or for specific groups of people. 🌐 How a company manages access and affordability is especially related to universal needs. Universal needs cover among other things health care 🏥, financial services🏦, utilities ⚡, education 📚 , and telecommunications 📠📱.

It is necessary that a product or a service live up to a certain degree of quality otherwise there is a risk of it having a health or safety risk to its users. 👷 This emphasizes product testing and management of ingredients such as chemicals in products. 🏭 It also covers management of the process put in place if there is an issue with a product and how it is recalled and withdrawn. 🤔

Customer welfare covers how a business provides products or services that are aligned with societal expectations. 📄 If we look at the food and beverage industry, it could be health and nutrition concerns and in animal production, it is e.g. the use of antibiotics. 💊

When business labels or markets a product, it should be done with transparency and accuracy so you as a user have the needed information regarding the product. 📦 This area also includes ethical marketing and selling practices as well as the risk of businesses providing customers with misleading labels. 😳

Labour practices cover compliance with labour laws and internationally accepted norms and standards. ⚖️ It covers human rights, child labour, forced or bonded labour, and fair wage to mention some of the basic workers' rights. ❤️

Health and safety of employees covers a workplace environment free of injuries, fatalities and illness. 🚑 This is upheld through having adequate safety management plans, training of employees as well as having audits of practices. 🗓 It is also important to look at how a business ensures its employees' mental health. 🤕

We all have biases and it is important to be aware of these biases for instance in hiring and promotion practices otherwise the business may discriminate against people. 😔 Discrimination can be based on e.g. race, gender, ethnicity, religion and sexual orientation. A business can include bias training of employees and look at the culture of the business in order to avoid discriminatory practices. 🤔 🌈

Product design and lifecycle management include lifecycle impacts meaning the impact of the product from production to distribution to the use of the product. 🔄 Product design covers how a business incorporates sustainable solutions to its product or service as well as how a business works with aligning to new environmental and societal regulations. ⚖️

Social, environmental, and political transitions demand capacity from a business. 💪 Business model resilience addresses a business' responsiveness to these transitions. 🔨 Examples of transitions can be a business' responsiveness to environmental transitions into e.g. low-carbon. Transitions can put businesses at risk of having to fundamentally change their business models to adapt to new realities. It is, therefore, necessary to show capacity to change accordingly. ⛑

Supply chain management covers environmental, social, and governance (ESG) risks within the chain. 🚛  Businesses should look into its suppliers in the supply chain and their environmental responsibility 🌱 and if suppliers respect e.g. for human rights ❤️ and work with anti-corruption 💰. To manage a supply chain a business needs to screen, monitor and engage with its suppliers. 🤝

Materials sourcing and efficiency cover the resilience of external environmental and social factors in the material supply chain. ⛓ The resilience is managed through product design, manufacturing, and using recycled and renewable materials. 🔄 Within materials sourcing and efficiency it is also covered how a business works with its suppliers regarding how resilient the suppliers are, this is done by looking at screening, selection, monitoring as well as engaging with suppliers. 🤝

Physical impacts of climate change cover any operational disruptions. Perational disruptions can be due to shifting climate, sea-level rise or extreme weather. 🌨🌪🌊 A business should manage these disruptions by building resilience towards climate change-related issues. 🌬 This can be done by planning and developing as well as by making insurance underwriting. 💼

Fraud, corruption, and bribery among others have an impact on business ethics. ⚖️ Managing risks related to ethical business conduct is important as it secures that a business is working in alignment with professional and ethical standards. 💼 A business should have adequate training for employees, and comprehensive policies and procedures in place to work with its business ethics. 🙌

Monopolies, excessive prices, insufficient service as well as inefficiencies all have a negative social impact. 😔 It is, therefore, important to be aware of how a business manages e.g. monopolistic, price-fixing, and anti-competitive risks. 🔍

When conflicting interests occur between corporate and public interests it can be addressed how a business engages with regulators as it can have long-term adverse environmental and social impacts. 😱 This flag also includes how much a business relies on e.g. a favourable regulatory environment. ⚖️

How a business manages risks and scenario planning to mitigate accidents and emergencies related to environmental and social issues will impact potential long-term effects on safety factors such as human, environmental, and social implications. 📝 Accidents can both harm the organization and its workers as well as society. ❤️

Systemic risk management covers a business' contribution to or management of risks related to systemic issues which can result in large-scale weakening or collapse of systems that the economy or society depends on. ⚖️

SDGs.description: About 1 billion people still live in poverty — defined as an income of less than US $1.25 per day. The targets under Goal 1 include aiming for a world where the poor are not vulnerable to climate change, and have “equal rights to economic resources.”
SDGs.subtitle: End poverty in all its forms everywhere
SDGs.title: No Poverty

SDGs.description: Ending hunger also includes ending malnutrition, protecting small farmers, and changing farming itself so that agriculture and ecosystems can co-exist. It also means protecting the genetic diversity of the crops we grow, while investing in research to make farming more and more productive, especially in developing countries. By 2030, we need to ensure that no one ever goes hungry.
SDGs.subtitle: End hunger, achieve food security and improved nutrition and promote sustainable agriculture
SDGs.title: Zero Hunger

SDGs.description: This Goal includes a comprehensive agenda for tackling a wide range of global health challenges, from tuberculosis and AIDS to traffic accidents and alcoholism. Goal 2 also calls for achieving “universal health coverage”; reducing illness and death caused by pollution; and increasing the global health workforce, especially in the world’s poorer countries.
SDGs.subtitle: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
SDGs.title: Good Health And Well-Being

SDGs.description: The Targets for Goal 4 cover the need for access to university-level education, vocational training, and entrepreneurship skills, and they pay special attention to issues of equity. This Goal also includes the promotion of education for sustainable development.
SDGs.subtitle: Ensure inclusive and quality education for all and promote lifelong learning
SDGs.title: Quality Education

SDGs.description: Equality and empowerment includes freedom from discrimination and violence. It also includes making sure woman have their equal share of leadership opportunities and responsibilities, as well as property ownership and other concrete reflections of power in society. Note that the Targets for this Goal make several references to the need to be nationally “appropriate” in interpreting what they mean.
SDGs.subtitle: Achieve gender equality and empower women and girls
SDGs.title: Gender Equality

SDGs.description: Basic water scarcity affects 40% of the global population, and nearly a billion people do not have access to that most basic of technologies: a toilet or latrine. The targets for this goal provide details for what we must do to rectify this situation, including protecting the ecosystems that provide the water in the first place.
SDGs.subtitle: Ensure access to water and sanitation for all
SDGs.title: Clean Water And Sanitation

SDGs.description: Globally, about 1.3 billion people live without access to electricity. Modern energy is also connected to access to water (Goal 6): you need energy to get water. In the wealthier countries, who have energy, this Goal pushes for a conversion to renewable sources, and it calls for dramatic improvements in efficienty everywhere.
SDGs.subtitle: Ensure access to affordable, reliable, sustainable and modern energy for all
SDGs.title: Affordable And Clean Energy

SDGs.description: At least 75 million young people around the world, aged 15-24, are unemployed, out of school, and looking at a bleak future. This Goal, while calling for economic growth to help close that gap, also calls for innovation and for “decoupling” growth from ecosystem degradation.
SDGs.subtitle: Promote inclusive and sustainable economic growth, employment and decent work for all
SDGs.title: Decent Work and Economic Growth

SDGs.description: "The world is becoming more industrialized, but often not in ways that are resilient and sustainable. This Goal aims for ensuring that everyone can enjoy the benefits of what humanity can build — and for fostering a much more innovative and environmentally sound approach to industrial development. "
SDGs.subtitle: Build resilient infrastructure, promote sustainable industrialization and foster innovation
SDGs.title: Industry, Innovation And Infrastructure

SDGs.description: The world is astonishingly unequal: the richest 80 people have the same wealth as the bottom 3.5 billion. The Goal includes a range of measures, including regulation of the financial markets, to make the playing field more level. Importantly, it also covers the issue of migration, which should be “orderly, safe, regular and responsible.”
SDGs.subtitle: Reduce inequality within and among countries
SDGs.title: Reduced Inequalities

SDGs.description: More than half the world lives in cities, and by 2050, at least 66% will — and most of the growth in cities is happening in Africa and Asia. If those cities are not sustainable, the world will not be, either. This Goal also covers issues like transportation, disaster preparedness, and even the preservation of “the world’s cultural and natural heritage.”
SDGs.subtitle: Make cities inclusive, safe, resilient and sustainable
SDGs.title: Sustainable Cities and Communities

SDGs.description: The world’s nations (through the UN) have already agreed to a “10-year framework” to make the way we produce and consume goods more sustainable. This Goal references that, but also covers topics like reducing food waste, corporate sustainability practice, public procurement, and making people aware of how their lifestyle choices make a difference.
SDGs.subtitle: Ensure sustainable consumption and production patterns
SDGs.title: Responsible consumption and production

SDGs.description: Goal 13 has an asterisk (*) after it, because in December 2015, another global negotiating process (UNFCCC) determined the details of the global agreement on climate action. That summit produced the “Paris Agreement,” which guides nations on their joint action to limit global warming to not more than 2 degrees C. (and preferably 1.5).
SDGs.subtitle: Take urgent action to combat climate change and its impacts
SDGs.title: Climate Action

SDGs.description: Global oceans and the life within them are over-fished, under-protected, and stressed from climate change and pollution. This Goal describes what we must do to save them — which includes research and learning, because we understand so little about what lies under the water’s surface. The SDGs have given the state of our oceans new visibility.
SDGs.subtitle: Conserve and sustainably use the oceans, seas and marine resources
SDGs.title: Life Below Water

SDGs.description: Life on land, on our beautiful planet Earth, is under terrible stress. This comprehensive Goal covers nearly every aspect of the threat to living ecosystems and biodiversity. We cannot afford to lose any more of nature — hence the repeated use of the word “halt” in the Targets section
SDGs.subtitle: Sustainably manage forests, combat desertification, halt and reverse land degradation, halt biodiversity loss
SDGs.title: Life On Land

SDGs.description: Reduce violence. End torture. Decrease the production and flow of arms. Reduce corruption. Create governments and institutions that work … for everyone. This important Goal also includes a Target that specifically calls for policies to promote sustainable development — which would certainly include the implementation of the SDGs themselves.
SDGs.subtitle: Promote just, peaceful and inclusive societies
SDGs.title: Peace, Jutice and strong institutions

SDGs.description: Goal 17 is about making sure all countries have what they need — funds, capacities, technologies, etc. — to achieve the rest of the SDGs. The Targets are a comprehensive list of such needs, including the need for partnerships and collaboration. Every country, every sector has a role to play!
SDGs.subtitle: Revitalize the global partnership for sustainable development
SDGs.title: Partnerships for the goals

sectors.description: The Aerospace and Defense Industry (A&D) comprises of manufacturers who develop spacecraft and aircraft for the military aircraft, commercial aircraft, tanks, missiles, and another weapon related equipment.
The Alternative energy(Renewable energy) sector includes companies that generate, distribute, and sell renewable and clean energy, and products and services related to it
The Automobiles & parts sector consists of companies manufacturing component parts for motor vehicles (cars, trucks)
All licensed financial institutions and financial holding companies
Beverage industry or drink industry comprises of companeis making drinks or ready-to drink products
The Chemical industry are a sum of companies manufacturing industrial chemicals
The Construction and Materials industry (Material) sector comprises of companies manufacturing construction materials (sand, cement)

The Diversified Industries covers a wide range of sub-sectors including Automotive, Transport & Logistics, Building Materials & Construction, Capital Goods, Business Services, Metals and Oil Field Services.
The Electricity sector comprises of all companies involve in manufacturing, transmission and distribution of electricity to homes and industry
The Electronic and Electrical Equipment sector comprises of companies that manufactures electronic supplies and equipment
The Equity Investment Instruments are products investing in stock(shares) of a company giving the holder part ownership of the company
The financial services sector comprises of companies those provide financial services to retail and corporate customers
The Fixed line telecommunications comprises of companies that provides wired networks that support fixed broadband and telephone services
The Food Producer sector comprises of companies involve in manufacturing, distributing and retaing of food products
The Forestry and Paper industry comprises of companies doing manufacturing of timber to produce customised wood and paper products.
The gas, water and multiutilities sector company stocks for several utilities services, including water, electricity, sewage, natural gas, and dams
The General Industries sector comprises of companies offering diversified products and services not harmful for public
The General Retailers sector consists of companies selling finished goods to end consumers

The healthcare equipment and services sector consists of companies and entities that provide medical equipment, medical supplies, and healthcare services, such as hospitals, home healthcare providers, and nursing homes.

The Household goods and home construction sector consists of companies dealing in goods and products used within households. They are the tangible and movable personal property placed in the household.
The Industrial Engineering sector comprises of companies combining manufacturing and industrial processes
The Industrial Metals & Mining sector comprises of companies
The industrial transportation sector comprises of companies involve in moving objects worked on or products in the production area
The Leisure Goods sector consists of companies focused on recreation, entertainment, sports, and tourism (REST)-related products and services.
The Life Insurance sector consists of companies offering risk management in the form of insurance contracts
The Media sector consists of companies sharing information (e.g. radio, television, newspapers, social media, video games, film and music etc.)
The mining sector consists of companies involved with the extraction of precious minerals and other geological materials
The mobile telecommunication sector consists of companies that transmit data in words, voice, audio, or video across the globe.
The non life insurance sector consists of companies selling general or non life insurance products including automobile, homeowner policies etc.
The Oil & Gas Producers sector consists of companies doing exploration, data acquisition, development, drilling, production, gathering, refining, distribution and transportation of hydrocarbons
The Oil Equipment, Services & Distribution sector consists of companies supplying equipment and services to oil fields and offshore platforms as well as operators of pipelines
The Personal Goods sector consists of companies involved in manufacturing and distribution of clothing, accessories, footwear, and personal care products
Discovering, developing, manufacturing and marketing new compounds for use in medicine, agriculture and industry.
The Real Estate Investment & Services consists of companies that invest in real estate directly through development, investment, or ownership or provide services to these companies
The Real Estate Investment Trusts are publicly traded company that owns, operates or finances income-producing properties or real estate
The Software & Computer Services sector consists of businesses concerned with the development, maintenance, and publication of software products

The Support Services Sector comprises companies primarily providing labour services ( e.g.commercial cleaning services, dining and catering services,  industrial maintenance services,  and other business support services.
Technology hardware and equipment sector consists of companies dealing in communications equipment; technology hardware, storage and peripherals; and electronic equipment, instruments and components.
The Travel & Leisure sector consistes of companies involved in recreation, entertainment, sports, and tourism (REST)-related products and services.
The Food and Drug retailers are owners and operators of supermarkets selling food and consumer staple products, general food retail stores, drug retail stores and pharmacies.

Sources.description: The Global 100 Index is an annual ranking of the world’s 100 most sustainable companies. The list is compiled by Toronto-based media and investment advisory firm, Corporate Knights.\nEach year, the latest version of the index in announced at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland. Corporate Knights have screened the companies themselves based on known data sources, and the list itself has been compiled on the basis of a thorough analysis of 7,400 companies from a variety of industries. Common to all of the companies is that they have a turnover of more than one billion USD.
Sources.subtitle: Global Top 100
Sources.title: Global Top 100

Sources.description: Science-based targets provide companies with a clearly defined pathway to future-proof growth by specifying how much and how quickly they need to reduce their greenhouse gas emissions.\nThe Science Based Targets initiative (SBTi) is a collaboration between CDP, World Resources Institute (WRI), the World Wide Fund for Nature (WWF), and the United Nations Global Compact (UN Global Compact) and one of the We Mean Business Coalition commitments.
Sources.subtitle: Science Based Targets
Sources.title: Science Based Targets

Sources.description: GoGetty is built on the vision that we can strengthen the push for diversity and inclusion in companies.\nThe GoGetty gender diversity score represents the average percentage of women and men in top management – showing current status as well as the company’s goals for the future. An ideal GoGetty gender diversity score equals 50%. The more ambitious goals, the higher the score.
Sources.subtitle: GoGetty
Sources.title: GoGetty

Sources.description: The world's largest corporate sustainability initiative\nThe United Nations Global Compact is a non-binding United Nations pact to encourage businesses worldwide to adopt sustainable and socially responsible policies, and to report on their implementation. The UN Global Compact is a principle-based framework for businesses, stating ten principles in the areas of human rights, labor, the environment and anti-corruption. Under the Global Compact, companies are brought together with UN agencies, labor groups and civil society. Cities can join the Global Compact through the Cities Programme.
Sources.subtitle: UN Global Compact
Sources.title: UN Global Compact

Sources.description: LCTPi is a unique, action-oriented program that brings together companies and partners to accelerate the development and deployment of low-carbon technology solutions to stay below the 2°C ceiling. LCTPi was launched at COP21 in Paris as CEOs publicly expressed support for LCTPi ambitions and mobilized their companies to implement inspiring sector-specific climate action plans.\n At WBCSD, almost 200 of the world’s forward-thinking companies work together to accelerate the transition to a sustainable world. WBCSD are a global, CEO-led organization whose mission is to accelerate the transition to a sustainable world by making more sustainable business more successful. WBCSDs vision is to build a world where nine billion people are living well and within the boundaries of the planet, by 2050.\n WBCSD’s mission and vision are ambitious. Driving long-term, sustainable change across our highly complex and interconnected world is not easy. No problem exists in isolation, and incremental change is no longer sufficient to fix the world’s most pressing challenges.
Sources.subtitle: Low Carbon Technology Partners Initiative
Sources.title: Low Carbon

Sources.description: The world’s most influential companies, committed to 100% renewable power. RE100 is a global corporate leadership initiative bringing together influential businesses committed to 100% renewable electricity.\n Led by The Climate Group in partnership with CDP, RE100’s purpose is to accelerate change towards zero carbon grids, at global scale. The initiative works to increase corporate demand for – and in turn supply of – renewable energy.\n
Sources.subtitle: Renewable Energy Top 100
Sources.title: Renewable Energy Top 100

Sources.description: The Climate Group’s global EP100 initiative in partnership with the  Alliance to Save Energy  brings together  a growing group of energy-smart companies  committed to improving their energy productivity and doing more with less. \n By integrating ambitious energy targets into business strategy, leading companies are  driving innovation in energy efficiency and increasing competitiveness while delivering on emissions reduction goals. \n The International Energy Agency (IEA) estimates that improvements in energy efficiency can deliver over 40% of the greenhouse gas emissions reductions needed to meet global climate goals. In addition to enabling a faster shift to renewables, energy efficiency improvements add enormous value to global GDP and boost companies’ bottom lines.
Sources.subtitle: EP100
Sources.title: EP100

Sources.description: below50 is a global campaign that brings together companies and organizations who commit to growing the global market for the world’s most sustainable fuels. We connect the entire value-chain for sustainable fuels that produce at least 50% less CO2 emissions than conventional fossil fuels. Our goal is to create the demand and market for these fuels to scale up their deployment.
Sources.subtitle: Below50
Sources.title: Below50

Sources.description: EV100 is a global initiative bringing together 60 forward-looking companies committed to accelerating the transition to electric vehicles (EVs) and making electric transport the new normal by 2030. Electric transport offers a major solution in cutting millions of tons of greenhouse gas emissions per year, as well as curbing transport related air and noise pollution.\n With businesses owning over half of all registered vehicles on the road, it is crucial that companies lead the shift to electric vehicles. Through their investment, and influence on millions of staff and customers worldwide, they can address rising global transport emissions. They can also significantly enhance mass demand for electric vehicles. By setting out their future EV purchasing requirements on an ambitious timescale, companies can drive mass roll-out and make electric cars more rapidly affordable for everyone around the world.
Sources.subtitle: EV100
Sources.title: EV100

Sources.description: The commodities soy, palm oil, beef, timber and pulp are wealth generators that feature in the supply chains of companies across economic sectors. By leading the agenda on how these commodities can be sustainably produced, forward-looking businesses are driving innovation, competitiveness and growth.\n Business has the power to alter global demand for the agricultural commodities that are the primary drivers of deforestation and forest degradation. And with deforestation accounting for approximately 15% of the world’s greenhouse gas emissions, the need for action has never been more urgent.\n By endorsing this initiative, companies commit to removing commodity-driven deforestation from their supply chains, combating a significant source of emissions and making their supply chains more sustainable and resilient.
Sources.subtitle: Remove Deforestation
Sources.title: Remove Deforestation

Sources.description: CSA 100 accelerates the adoption of Climate Smart Agriculture (CSA) in the food, beverage and agriculture sector. Showing that business plays a critical role in meeting the Paris Agreement, the initiative brings together 100 influential companies to make science-based and measurable commitments to 2030, across three pillars: Productivity, resilience and mitigation.\n Leading companies dependent on agriculture for their continued success recognize the urgent need to build climate-change resilience within the sector, cut greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions and sustainably increase agricultural productivity and incomes.\n Making progress on mitigation in the food and agriculture sector is particularly crucial to meet the Paris Agreement, as it represents 25% of all GHG emissions. It is also the sector most vulnerable to climate change, and yet it must grow substantially in order to meet the daily nutritional needs of 10 billion people by 2050.
Sources.subtitle: Climate Smart Agriculture
Sources.title: Climate Smart Agriculture

Sources.description: Tackling ‘short-lived climate pollutants’ (SLCPs) – including methane, black carbon,tropospheric ozone or hydro uorocarbons (HFCs) – is vital to reduce near-term global warming and improve human well-being.\n Businesses taking action to reduce these emissions can deliver rapid and measurable benefits in air quality, public health and food security whilst also boosting economic growth and making a key contribution to global climate change mitigation efforts.
Sources.subtitle: Reduce SLCPs
Sources.title: Reduce SLCPs

Sources.description: A growing group of forward-looking companies are using an internal carbon price to help manage climate risk and align themselves with the low-carbon transition.\n Internal carbon pricing can not only help companies effectively combat climate change and meet bold emissions reduction targets, but can also encourage innovation, drive down costs and help ensure sustained economic competitiveness.\n Leading businesses recognize this and are building a carbon price into their operations and investment decisions, as an effective way to future-proof profitability and help shape the evolving regulatory framework.
Sources.subtitle: Carbon Pricing Leadership Coalition
Sources.title: Carbon Pricing Leadership Coalition

Sources.description: A supportive policy framework is vital to give business the backing it needs in the transition to a low-carbon economy. This is why forward-looking companies are actively ensuring their policy engagement on key climate issues is aligned, transparent, and consistent.\n The “Guide for Responsible Corporate Engagement in Climate Policy” sets out a program of action for companies wishing to demonstrate best practice in policy engagement.\n Early action and leadership will be beneficial to companies’ bottom lines and will promote their work to institutional investors. Companies will also be in a strong position for benchmarking and for future CDP performance scoring of this activity area.
Sources.subtitle: Responsible Climate Policy
Sources.title: Responsible Climate Policy

Sources.description: The CDSB Climate Change Reporting Framework is a voluntary reporting framework designed to elicit climate change-related information of value to investors in mainstream financial reports. \n Created in line with the objectives of financial reporting and rules on non-financial reporting, the Climate Change Reporting Framework seeks to filter out what is required to understand how climate change affects a company’s financial performance and value creation. Information prepared in accordance with the Climate Change Reporting Framework enables investors to make informed and robust decisions. These are based on clarity, confidence and trust in climate-change related opportunities and risks disclosed by a company, understanding their comparative position with respect to future challenges and opportunities.
Sources.subtitle: Report Climate Change Information
Sources.title: Report Climate Change Information

Sources.description: Preparing for and adapting to new climate realities will be one of the defining challenges of the 21st century. Recognizing the considerable environmental, social, and economic value at stake due to worsening water stress and climate change, the private sector has come together to create the Business Alliance for Water and Climate (BAFWAC).\n So far, over 40 companies with $650 billion in annual revenues have made this commitment. BAFWAC’s target is to reach 100 signatories with representing $1 trillion in revenues by 2018.\n BAFWAC was jointly launched by CDP, the CEO Water Mandate, SUEZ, and the World Business Council for Sustainable Development in December 2015 and has since been endorsed by the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change. Each year, BAFWAC tracks and reports the progress of signatory companies towards the commitment at the UNFCCC Conference of Parties.
Sources.subtitle: Improve Water Security
Sources.title: Improve Water Security

Sources.description: SOS 1.5 is a cross-sectorial framework to help companies transform their operations and align with 1.5°C. SOS 1.5 helps companies identify the barriers to overcome and actions needed to accelerate our transition. Replacing the Low Carbon Technology Partnership Initiative, SOS 1.5 provides sector-specific deep dives and a tailored roadmap for any company to achieve climate action, regardless of where they are on the journey. SOS 1.5 is an action initiative of the We Mean Business coalition.
Sources.title: SOS 1.5

texts.Letter of Consent:
For the purposes of investment, MakeImpact IVS would like to disclose your personal data to your own bank. We disclose the following personal data: First Name, Last Name, Age, Gender, E-mail, Country of Residence, Name of the users Bank, Telephone number, Amount of interest, Chosen company. 

  

 Your consent is given to us voluntarily and you have the right to withdraw it at any time by contacting us per e-mail hello@makeimpact.io. If you withdraw the consent, this will not affect the lawfulness of the processing and disclosure prior to the withdrawal, but we will no longer use your consent as a legal basis for anything we do with your personal data.
texts.Signup Legal:
PRIVACY NOTICE FOR USERS OF MAKEIMPACT 
 
  This privacy notice applies to the users of MakeImpact’s services, incl. our website and web-based app (app.makeimpact.io) as well as business partners, which we may be in contact with as part of our business.  

  WE ARE THE DATA CONTROLLER

  MakeImpact IVS (“MakeImpact”) is the Data Controller for the processing of your personal data. Our contact information is: 

 
 MAKEIMPACT IVS
 ØSTER SØGADE 112, ST. TH
 2100 KØBENHAVN Ø
 CVR-NO.: 39899639
 E-MAIL ADDRESS: HELLO@MAKEIMPACT.IO
 TEL NO: +45 27 57 20 32


    1.	CATEGORIES OF PERSONAL DATA 
 We collect and process the following types of personal data: 
 
 1.1 USERS: 
 Visitors of the web-based app: Age, Gender and Favorite SDGs. 
 Signed up users: First Name, Last Name, Age, Gender, E-mail, Country of Residence, Name of the users Bank, Favorite SDGs and favorite companies the user follows. 
 Users which declare interest in a specific company: First Name, Last Name, Age, Gender, E-mail, Country of Residence, Name of the users Bank, Telephone number, Amount of interest, Chosen company. 

 1.2 PARTNERS AND OTHER INDIVIDUALS: 
 Business Partners and Individuals: First Name, Last Name, E-mail, Phone number, Company, Position. 
 Individuals receiving marketing and newsletters: First Name, Last Name and E-mail. 


  2.	WHERE DO WE COLLECT YOUR PERSONAL DATA FROM? 
 We do not collect other personal data than the personal data you have given us directly. 

    3.	THE PURPOSES AND LEGAL BASIS FOR THE COLLECTION AND PROCESSING OF THE PERSONAL DATA

  Visitors of  the web based app: We collect information about your age and gender and chosen SDGs to find potential investment ideas targeted your profile as well as for statistical and research purposes based on our legitimate interests in analyzing our potential customer segment and user group of our website and teaser, cf. GDPR art. 6(1)(f), cf. the Danish Data Protection Act section 6. 
 Signed up users: Our processing is necessary to fulfil our contract with you, cf. GDPR art. 6(1)(b), cf. the Danish Data Protection Act section 6. 
 Users which declare interest in a specific company: Our processing is necessary to fulfil our contract with you, cf. GDPR art. 6(1)(b), cf. the Danish Data Protection Act section 6. 
 Business Partners and Individuals: Our processing is based on our legitimate interests in ensuring necessary day-to-day contact with our current and potential business partners. 
 Individuals receiving marketing, newsletters: We send marketing material, incl. newsletters and invitations to events, based on your consent, cf. art. 6(1)(a), cf. the Danish Marketing Practices Act section 10. 

 All of the above: 
 •	To handle day to day communication. 
 •	To comply with applicable personal data protection regulation and other legitimate interests, e.g. compliance with basic principles and legal grounds for processing personal data; putting in place, maintaining and testing technical and organizational security measures; investigating and reporting suspected personal data breaches, if any; handling requests and complaints from data subjects and others, if any; establishment, exercise or defense of legal claims; handling inspections and queries by supervisory authorities, if any; handling disputes with data subjects and third parties, if any. 

 You provide the above-mentioned personal data voluntarily to us. You are not obliged to provide the personal data to us except if it follows from a legal obligation. The consequences of not providing the personal data may be that we cannot fulfil our part of the agreement, incl. that we cannot proceed with any investment enquiries. 
 In relation to marketing and newsletters, you are not obliged to provide the personal data to us, which means that you will not receive any marketing or newsletters from us. 

  3.1 DISCLOSURE OF THE PERSONAL DATA TO OTHER DATA CONTROLLERS

 As part of our services to you, we will disclose and share your personal data to: 
 •	Your own bank
 •	Third Parties and Partner, e.g. MailChimp and Google Firebase. 
 •	Regulatory and government bodies when required, e.g. the Danish Data Protection Agency or tax authorities. 
 
 The legal basis for the disclosure of the personal data is the following: 
 •	Your consent to the disclosure of your personal information to your own bank, cf. GDPR art. 6(1)(a). 
 •	Third Parties and Partner, cf. GDPR art. 6(1)(b) 
 •	Our legal obligations, if any, cf. GDPR art. 6(1)(c). 

   3.2 TRANSFER OF PERSONAL DATA TO DATA PROCESSORS 
 We currently use Google Firebase and MailChimp as our providers of online communication. Google Firebase is used to store your user information and data for the MakeImpact app, here we store all the data you provide us with, but we do not register or store any information from third parties about you. In MailChimp we register information such as your first name, last name and e-mail in order to contact you with the information you have consented to e.g. newsletters and updates from MakeImpact. 
  In addition, we use Google Firebase for analytical and statistical purposes e.g. tracking the time you spend on our website and your behavior at the website, in order to improve your experience with our services at MakeImpact.io.  
  Furthermore we use Google Analytics to measure and analyse the traffic and usage of our website and app with the aim of improving your experience with our services. In connection herewith Google handles your IP address and behaviour, when you use our website and app. You can decline the usage of Google Analytics by installing an ad-on to your browser by following this link: https://tools.google.com/dlpage/gaoptout 
  Both Google and MailChimp are a part of the Privacy Shield agreement.  
 Google Analytics is in Europe provided by Google Ireland Limited located at Gordon House, Barrow Street, Dublin 4, Ireland. 
 

 3.3 INTERNATIONAL TRANSFERS OF PERSONAL DATA (TO COUNTRIES OUTSIDE THE EU/EEA) 
 We transfer your personal data to the following recipients located in countries outside the EU/EEA. The transfer basis is the EU-U.S. Privacy Shield: 
  •	Google Firebase Inc, 22 4th Street, Suite 1000 (10th Floor), San Francisco, CA 94103, USA
 •	MailChimp, Rocket Science Group LLC, 675 Ponce De Leon Ave NE, Suite 5000, Atlanta, GA 30308, USA. 


  3.4 WITHDRAWAL OF CONSENT 
 You have the right to withdraw your consent to the processing or disclosure of your personal data. If you withdraw the consent, this will not affect the lawfulness of the processing and disclosure prior to the withdrawal, but we will no longer use your consent as a legal basis for anything we do with your personal data. Please contact us using the contact details below if you wish to exercise this right. 


  3.5 RETENTION PERIOD
 •	We store the personal data for as long as necessary to fulfil the purposes above. 
 •	Personal data about visitors on websites are not stored as we only use session cookies. 
 •	Personal data used for marketing purposes, incl. newsletters, are stored for 2 years starting from the day documentation of the consent is collected, withdrawn or last used (the latest one of these). 


  3.6 YOUR RIGHTS
 Subject to the conditions set out in the applicable data protection legislation, you enjoy the following certain rights: 

  •	The right to request access to the personal data
 •	The right to rectification of the personal data
 •	The right to erasure of the personal data
 •	The right to restriction of processing
 •	The right to data portability
 •	The right to objection to the processing of the personal data
  You also have the right to file a complaint with the competent supervisory authority, such as the Danish Data Protection Agency. Please consult their website for how to submit a complaint at www.datatilsynet.dk. 


   3.7 LEGITIMATE INTERESTS: 
 You have the right to object, on grounds relating to your particular situation, at any time to our processing of personal data which uses ‘legitimate interests’ as a legal basis for the processing (as set out in article 6(1)(f) of the GDPR). Where you have exercised this right to object, we will no longer process your personal data on the legal basis of ‘legitimate interests’ unless we can demonstrate compelling legitimate grounds for the processing, which override your interests, rights and freedoms or if the processing is necessary for the establishment, exercise or defense of legal claims. 


 3.8 DIRECT MARKETING: 
 Where your personal data are processed for direct marketing purposes, you have the right to object at any time to processing of personal data concerning you for such marketing, which includes profiling to the extent that it is related to such direct marketing. Where you object to the processing for direct marketing purposes, your personal data will no longer be processed for such purposes. 


 3.8 CONTACT
 Please contact us at hello@makeimpact.io if you have any questions in regards to the protection of your personal data or if you wish to exercise any of the legal rights set out in this Privacy Notice.

legal.text:
<bold>1. Introduction</bold>
 Make!mpact (hereinafter also referred to as "us" or "we") is a Nordic startup, based in Copenhagen, who empowers you with the knowledge, confidence and transparency to make a difference through your investments.

 The following Legal Terms provide us with the legal user consent required in order for us to share and disclose user data with a third party provider such as a bank and/or investment platform as well as obtaining the legal consent for direct email marketing to the user. It is therefore important that you read these Legal Terms closely and also familiarise yourself with our Privacy Policy stated on our website.

  <bold>2. Legal Terms</bold>

 <bold>By signing up to the make!mpact platform, I hereby give permission to make!mpact to share my personal data with my own bank and/or investment platform as described below and in the Privacy Policy of make!mpact.</bold>

 <bold>I also hereby give permission to make!mpact to share my personal data with other banks, investment platforms, and other financial institutions than my own bank as described below and in the Privacy Policy of make!mpact.</bold>

 For the purpose of encouraging, guiding and mobilizing our make!mpact members the best way possible on their sustainable investment journey, we would like to disclose your personal data to your own bank and/or investment platform. We will disclose one or more of the following personal data: First Name, Last Name, Age, Gender, E-mail, Country of Residence, Name of your Bank, Your Phone Number (Optional), Your Level of Investment Experience and Your Values defined as one or more of the 17 UN Sustainable Development Goals.

 Your consent is given to us voluntarily and you have the right to withdraw it at any time by contacting us per e-mail hello@makeimpact.io. If you withdraw the consent, this will not affect the lawfulness of the processing and disclosure prior to the withdrawal, but we will no longer use your consent as a legal basis for anything we do with your personal data.

 <bold>Lastly, I also hereby give make!mpact permission to add me to their newsletter mailing list via email containing marketing about the business of make!mpact and upcoming events. It is possible to unsubscribe at <underline>any time</underline> by using the unsubscribe link in each email.</bold>

 You can read more about how we process your personal data in our Privacy Policy on our website www.makeimpact.io
legal.title: Make!mpact Legal Terms

privacy.text:
<bold>Privacy Policy 2022 for users of Make!mpact</bold>

 This Privacy Policy applies to the users of make!mpact’s services, incl. our website and web-based app (app.makeimpact.io) as well as business partners, which we may be in contact with as part of our business.

 <bold>We are the Data Controller</bold>
 MakeImpact IVS (“Make!mpact”) is the Data Controller for the processing of your personal data. Our contact information is:
 MakeImpact IVS
 Birkedommervej 27, 2 sal
 2400 København NV
 CVR-no.: 39899639
 E-mail address: hello@makeimpact.io
 Tel no: +45 27 57 20 32

 <bold>Categories of personal data</bold>
 We collect and process the following types of personal data:

 <bold>Users </bold>
 Signed up users of the web-based app: First Name, Last Name, Age, Gender, E-mail, Country of Residence, Name of your Bank, Your Phone Number (Optional), Your Level of Investment Experience and Your Values defined as one or more of the 17 UN Sustainable Development Goals.

 <bold>Partners and Other     Individuals</bold>
 Business Partners and Individuals: First Name, Last Name, E-mail, Phone number, Company, Position.
 Individuals receiving marketing and newsletters: First Name, Last Name, and E-mail.

 <bold>Where do we     collect your personal data from?</bold>
 We do not collect other personal data than the personal data you have given us directly.

 <bold>The purposes and legal basis for the collection and processing of the personal data 
 </bold> 
 Signed up users: We collect the above-mentioned information about you to find potential investment ideas targeted your profile as well as for statistical and research purposes based on our legitimate interests in analyzing our potential customer segment and user group of our website and teaser, cf. GDPR art. 6(1)(f), cf. the Danish Data Protection Act section 6 and our further processing are necessary to fulfill our contract with you, cf. GDPR art. 6(1)(b), cf. the Danish Data Protection Act section 6.
 Business Partners and Individuals: Our processing is based on our legitimate interests in ensuring necessary day-to-day contact with our current and potential business partners.
 Individuals receiving marketing, newsletters: We send marketing material, incl. newsletters and invitations to events, based on your consent, cf. art. 6(1)(a), cf. the Danish Marketing Practices Act section 10.

 All of the above:
 To handle day to day communication.
 To comply with applicable personal data protection regulation and other legitimate interests, e.g. compliance with basic principles and legal grounds for processing personal data; putting in place, maintaining and testing technical and organisational security measures; investigating and reporting suspected personal data breaches, if any; handling requests and complaints from data subjects and others, if any; establishment, exercise or defense of legal claims; handling inspections and queries by supervisory authorities, if any; handling disputes with data subjects and third parties, if any.
 You provide the above mentioned personal data voluntarily to us. You are not obliged to provide the personal data to us except if it follows from a legal obligation. The consequences of not providing the personal data may be that we cannot fulfill our part of the agreement, incl. that we cannot proceed with any investment inquiries.
 In relation to marketing and newsletters, you are not obliged to provide personal data to us, which means that you will not receive any marketing or newsletters from us.

 <bold>Disclosure of the personal data to other data     controllers</bold>
 As part of our services to you, we will disclose and share your personal data to:
 Your own bank and/or an investment platform.
 Third Parties and Partner, e.g. MailChimp and Google Firebase.
 Regulatory and government bodies when required, e.g. the Danish Data Protection Agency or tax authorities.

 The legal basis for the disclosure of the personal data is the following:
 Your consent to the disclosure of your personal information to your own bank and/or an investment platform., cf. GDPR art. 6(1)(a).
 Third Parties and Partner, cf. GDPR art. 6(1)(b)
 Our legal obligations, if any, cf. GDPR art. 6(1)(c).

 <bold>Transfer of personal data to data processors</bold>
 We currently use Google Firebase and MailChimp as our providers of online communication. Google Firebase is used to store your user information and data for the MakeImpact app, here we store all the data you provide us with but we do not register or store any information from third parties about you. In MailChimp we register information such as your first name, last name and e-mail in order to contact you with the information you have consented to e.g. newsletters and updates from MakeImpact.

 In addition, we use Google Firebase for analytical and statistical purposes e.g. tracking the time you spend on our website and your behavior at the website, in order to improve your experience with our services at MakeImpact.io.

 Furthermore, we use Google Analytics to measure and analyse the traffic and usage of our website and app with the aim of improving your experience with our services. In connection herewith Google handles your IP address and behaviour when you use our website and app. You can decline the usage of Google Analytics by installing an add-on to your browser by following this link: tools.google.com/dlpage/gaoptout 

 Both Google Firebase and MailChimp are a part of the Privacy Shield agreement.

 Google Analytics is in Europe provided by Google Ireland Limited located at Gordon House, Barrow Street, Dublin 4, Ireland.

 <bold>International transfers of personal data     (to countries outside the EU/EEA)</bold>
 We transfer your personal data to the following recipients located in countries outside the EU/EEA. The transfer basis is the EU-U.S. Privacy Shield:
 Google Firebase Inc, 22 4th Street, Suite 1000 (10th Floor), San Francisco, CA 94103, USA
 MailChimp, Rocket Science Group LLC, 675 Ponce De Leon Ave NE, Suite 5000, Atlanta, GA 30308, USA.

 <bold>Withdrawal of consent</bold>
 You have the right to withdraw your consent to the processing or disclosure of your personal data. If you withdraw the consent, this will not affect the lawfulness of the processing and disclosure prior to the withdrawal, but we will no longer use your consent as a legal basis for anything we do with your personal data. Please contact us using the contact details below if you wish to exercise this right.

 <bold>Retention period</bold>
 We store the personal data for as long as necessary to fulfill the purposes above.
 Personal data about visitors on websites are not stored as we only use session cookies.
 Personal data used for marketing purposes, incl. newsletters are stored for 2 years starting from the day documentation of the consent is collected, withdrawn or last used (the latest one of these).

 <bold>Your rights</bold>
 Subject to the conditions set out in the applicable data protection legislation, you enjoy the following certain rights:
 The right to request access to the personal data
 The right to rectification of the personal data
 The right to erasure of the personal data
 The right to restriction of processing
 The right to data portability
 The right to objection to the processing of the personal data
 You also have the right to file a complaint with the competent supervisory authority, such as the Danish Data Protection Agency. Please consult their website for how to submit a complaint at www.datatilsynet.dk. 

 <bold>Legitimate interests:</bold>
 You have the right to object, on grounds relating to your particular situation, at any time to our processing of personal data which uses ‘legitimate interests’ as a legal basis for the processing (as set out in article 6(1)(f) of the GDPR). Where you have exercised this right to object, we will no longer process your personal data on the legal basis of ‘legitimate interests’ unless we can demonstrate compelling legitimate grounds for the processing, which override your interests, rights, and freedoms or if the processing is necessary for the establishment, exercise or defense of legal claims.

 <bold>Direct marketing:</bold>
 Where your personal data are processed for direct marketing purposes, you have the right to object at any time to processing of personal data concerning you for such marketing, which includes profiling to the extent that it is related to such direct marketing. Where you object to the processing for direct marketing purposes, your personal data will no longer be processed for such purposes.

 <bold>Contact</bold>
 Please contact us at hello@makeimpact.io if you have any questions in regards to the protection of your personal data or if you wish to exercise any of the legal rights set out in this Privacy Policy.
privacy.title: Privacy Policy
